title: Dancing On Ice beats Strictly Come Dancing to first same-sex couple contestants
text:
Matt Evers and Ian ‘H’ Watkins are partnered together (Picture: Rex)

Dancing On Ice is thought to have made television history by welcoming its first same-sex couple on the upcoming 2020 series – beating Strictly Come Dancing to the milestone move.

One week after the official line-up was announced, it’s been alleged that professional skater Matt Evers has paired up with Steps singer Ian Watkins aka H ahead of the ITV competition returning in January.

‘After conversations with the Dancing on Ice production team, H enquired as to the possibility of being paired with a male pro skater,’ a source told Metro.co.uk.

They continued: ‘Dancing on Ice were fully supportive of a same-sex partnership and as such this year H will be paired with Matt Evers.’

A spokesperson told us: ‘We won’t be commenting on speculation around the Dancing on Ice pairings until closer to the new series in 2020.’

Last year, former Dancing On Ice judge Jason Gardiner backed the call for same-sex couples to join the rink.

Steps singer H reportedly asked to be matched with a male professional (Picture: ITV)

Strictly has yet to see same-sex couples compete (Picture: PA)

‘I’m sure ITV would have no problem with embracing it,’ he said. ‘It would be great to have a same-sex couple.’

However the panelist, who has now been replaced by John Barrowman, was quick to add that those in a same-sex partnership may have their work cut out for them.

Jason explained: ‘When you’ve got two men, generally you’ve got similar heights and weights.

‘That’s when it starts getting difficult. It’s very difficult to put somebody your own size above your head.’

Dancing On Ice rival show Strictly has yet to make the move to same-sex couples dancing together on the show.

However, back in August, a BBC spokesperson told Metro.co.uk that they are open to the idea.

Strictly Come Dancing is an inclusive show and we are proud to have featured same sex dancing amongst the professional dancers in group numbers in previous series.

‘We are completely open to the prospect of including same sex pairings between our celebrities and professional dancers in the future, should the opportunity arise.’
